intro: Hydrocotyle acuminata var. boliviana, commonly known as the Bolivian marsh penny, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the Araliaceae family and is characterized by its broad, heart-shaped leaves that often float on the surface of shallow water. The plant produces small, white flowers that are typically clustered in umbels, which are borne on slender stems. It thrives in wetland environments and is often found in marshes and along the edges of ponds. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in water gardens.
